title: Phyllodes Tumor Requiring Wide Excision
setup_script: A 42-year-old woman presents with a rapidly enlarging 5 cm mass in her left breast. Ultrasound shows a solid, lobulated lesion; core biopsy suggests a phyllodes tumor.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Take history including duration of tumor growth, prior fibroadenomas, and any systemic symptoms.
Perform clinical breast exam; note size, mobility, and skin involvement; assess axilla for nodes.
Order mammography and ultrasound to evaluate tumor characteristics; consider MRI for size estimation.
Discuss pathology results indicating phyllodes tumor and its spectrum (benign, borderline, malignant).
Explain that phyllodes tumors require wide local excision with 1 cm margins due to high recurrence risk.
Plan surgical approach: wide local excision; consider oncoplastic techniques to maintain cosmesis given large size.
Obtain informed consent; explain risk of recurrence and rare potential for metastasis in malignant phyllodes.
Perform wide excision; orient specimen; send for pathology to determine grade and margins.
If margins positive, plan re-excision to achieve clear margins; discuss possibility of mastectomy if unable to obtain adequate margins.
Postoperative care: manage wound, monitor for hematoma, and discuss pathology results with patient.
Long-term follow-up: schedule surveillance exams and imaging every 6 months for first 2 years due to recurrence risk.
Educate patient on self-examination and prompt evaluation for new lumps; offer psychological support due to anxiety of recurrence.

critical_decision_points: Correct diagnosis of phyllodes tumor and understanding of its subtypes.
Importance of wide local excision with clear margins to prevent recurrence.
Oncoplastic techniques to optimize cosmetic outcome in large tumors.
Management of positive margins and consideration of mastectomy.
Follow-up schedule and patient education regarding recurrence risk.
